title: Object-Oriented Programming (OOP)
description: OOP is a programming paradigm based on the concept of 'objects', which can contain data and code. The four main pillars of OOP in Java are:
points: Encapsulation: Bundling data and methods that operate on that data within a single unit (class).
Inheritance: Mechanism where a new class inherits properties and behaviors from an existing class.
Polymorphism: Ability of an object to take on many forms (e.g., method overloading and overriding).
Abstraction: Hiding complex implementation details and showing only the essential features of the object.

title: JVM, JRE, and JDK
description: Understanding the Java ecosystem structure is crucial for every developer.
points: JDK (Java Development Kit): The full development environment including the JRE, compilers (javac), and tools.
JRE (Java Runtime Environment): The runtime environment required to run Java applications. Includes JVM and libraries.
JVM (Java Virtual Machine): The engine that executes Java bytecode. It provides platform independence (Write Once, Run Anywhere).

title: Java Collections Framework
description: A unified architecture for representing and manipulating collections of objects.
points: List: Ordered collection (e.g., ArrayList, LinkedList). Allows duplicates.
Set: Unordered collection that does not allow duplicates (e.g., HashSet, TreeSet).
Map: Object that maps keys to values. No duplicate keys allowed (e.g., HashMap, TreeMap).
Queue: Collection used to hold multiple elements prior to processing (e.g., PriorityQueue).

title: Exception Handling
description: Mechanism to handle runtime errors and maintain normal application flow.
points: Checked Exceptions: Exceptions checked at compile-time (e.g., IOException). Must be handled.
Unchecked Exceptions: Exceptions occurring at runtime (e.g., NullPointerException). Optional handling.
Try-Catch-Finally: Block structure to handle exceptions and execute cleanup code.

title: Java Streams API
description: Introduced in Java 8 to process sequences of elements declaratively.
points: Intermediate Operations: Transform a stream into another stream (e.g., filter, map, sorted). Lazy execution.
Terminal Operations: Produce a result or side-effect (e.g., collect, forEach, reduce). Triggers processing.
Parallel Streams: Enable parallel processing of data leveraging multi-core architectures.

title: Multithreading & Concurrency
description: Concurrent execution of two or more parts of a program for maximum CPU utilization.
points: Thread Class vs Runnable Interface: Two ways to create threads.
Synchronization: Controlling access to shared resources to prevent thread interference.
Executor Framework: Higher-level API for managing thread pools and execution.

title: Inversion of Control (IoC) & DI
description: The core principle of the Spring Framework that decouples object creation from their usage.
points: IoC Container: Manages the lifecycle and configuration of application objects (Beans).
Dependency Injection (DI): Dependencies are 'injected' into objects via Constructor, Setter, or Field injection.
Benefits: Loose coupling, easier testing, and better code maintainability.

title: Aspect-Oriented Programming (AOP)
description: A paradigm to increase modularity by separating cross-cutting concerns.
points: Cross-cutting Concerns: Logic used across multiple modules (e.g., Logging, Security, Transaction).
Aspect: Module encapsulating a concern.
Advice: Action taken at a join point (Before, After, Around).

title: Spring Bean Scopes
description: Defines the lifecycle and visibility of Spring beans.
points: Singleton: Default scope. Only one instance per Spring container.
Prototype: A new instance is created every time the bean is requested.
Request/Session: Scopes specific to web-aware Spring ApplicationContext.

title: Spring MVC Flow
description: Request processing workflow in Spring Web MVC.
points: DispatcherServlet: Front controller that receives all requests.
HandlerMapping: Maps request to appropriate Controller.
ViewResolver: Resolves logical view names to actual views (JSP, Thymeleaf).

title: Spring Boot Auto-Configuration
description: Opinionated defaults to configure Spring applications automatically.
points: @EnableAutoConfiguration: Triggers auto-configuration based on classpath dependencies.
Conditional Configuration: Beans are created only if specific classes or properties are present.
Benefits: Eliminates boilerplate configuration code.

title: Spring Boot Actuator
description: Production-ready features to monitor and manage your application.
points: Endpoints: Exposes operational information (e.g., /health, /metrics, /info).
Customization: Create custom endpoints or secure existing ones.
Health Checks: Monitor database connections, disk space, and other components.

title: Key Spring Boot Annotations
description: Essential annotations for building Spring Boot applications.
points: @SpringBootApplication: Meta-annotation combining @Configuration, @EnableAutoConfiguration, and @ComponentScan.
@RestController: Specialized version of @Controller that automatically writes response to body.
@Service, @Repository, @Component: Stereotype annotations for defining beans.

title: Database Normalization
description: Process of organizing data to reduce redundancy and improve integrity.
points: 1NF: Atomic values, no repeating groups.
2NF: 1NF + no partial dependencies.
3NF: 2NF + no transitive dependencies.

title: ACID Properties
description: Guarantees for reliable database transactions.
points: Atomicity: All operations in a transaction succeed or fail together.
Consistency: Database moves from one valid state to another.
Isolation: Concurrent transactions do not affect each other.
Durability: Committed data is saved permanently.

title: Indexes
description: Data structures that improve speed of data retrieval operations.
points: Clustered Index: Sorts and stores data rows in the table based on key values (Primary Key).
Non-Clustered Index: Structure separate from data rows. Contains key values and pointers to data.
Trade-off: Faster reads (SELECT) but slower writes (INSERT/UPDATE/DELETE).

title: SQL Joins
description: Clause used to combine rows from two or more tables.
points: INNER JOIN: Returns records with matching values in both tables.
LEFT JOIN: Returns all records from left table, and matched records from right.
RIGHT JOIN: Returns all records from right table, and matched records from left.
FULL OUTER JOIN: Returns all records when there is a match in either left or right.

title: Big O Notation
description: Mathematical notation to describe algorithm efficiency.
points: O(1): Constant Time - direct access.
O(log n): Logarithmic Time - binary search.
O(n): Linear Time - simply looping through elements.
O(n log n): Linearithmic Time - effective sorting (Merge Sort, Quick Sort).
O(n^2): Quadratic Time - nested loops.

title: Common Data Structures
description: Ways of organizing and storing data for efficient access and modification.
points: Array: Contiguous memory locations. Fast access O(1), fixed size.
LinkedList: Nodes with data and address. Dynamic size, slow access O(n).
Stack: LIFO (Last In First Out). Push/Pop operations.
Queue: FIFO (First In First Out). Enqueue/Dequeue operations.
HashMap: Key-Value pairs. Fast lookups O(1) avg.

title: Essential Algorithms
description: Step-by-step procedures for calculations and data processing.
points: Sorting: Bubble, Selection, Insertion, Merge, Quick Sort.
Searching: Linear Search, Binary Search.
Graph Traversal: BFS (Breadth-First Search), DFS (Depth-First Search).
Dynamic Programming: Breaking down problems into simpler sub-problems.
